text:
It boils down to how long they have been working for you and how much more you need their involvement in your project.

there's absolutely no question that they would benefit from having access to analytics. Knowing you are creating direct value is not only a great feeling, it's direct feedback that the writer can use to make their product on YOUR website better.

so if that's a desirable effect, give them access for a month and see how they do

as for learning from GA, it's definitely a skill and ideally, they should know it or at least should be curious about learning it. If they have access to GA for a month, you can check with them how much are they willing to invest themselves into learning GA

elements.text:

as for learning from GA, it's definitely a skill and ideally, they should know it or at least should be curious about learning it. If they have access to GA for a month, you can check with them how much are they willing to invest themselves into learning GA

text: What's a startup you think is doing content marketing right & operating like a media company (SME interviews, hot takes, thought leadership pieces, creating demand through their content)? I love what Cleo and Catalyst are doing :nerd_face:

elements.text: What's a startup you think is doing content marketing right & operating like a media company (SME interviews, hot takes, thought leadership pieces, creating demand through their content)? I love what Cleo and Catalyst are doing

text: I'm sharing data on how their pieces perform to keep them updated, motivated, and willing to do more of the same (usually every month, sharing top-level data such as unique organic hits for all the articles a freelancer has done, or how many signups and free trials their articles have brought us -> it's easier when you're self serve, B2C SaaS business to get super meaningful metrics fast). But, ultimately, I'm solely responsible for OKRs (tracking, gathering, and subsequently, fulfilling and strategizing about the next steps).

elements.text: I'm sharing data on how their pieces perform to keep them updated, motivated, and willing to do more of the same (usually every month, sharing top-level data such as unique organic hits for all the articles a freelancer has done, or how many signups and free trials their articles have brought us -> it's easier when you're self serve, B2C SaaS business to get super meaningful metrics fast). But, ultimately, I'm solely responsible for OKRs (tracking, gathering, and subsequently, fulfilling and strategizing about the next steps).

text: To me, that seems like a different role than just a freelance writer. All of the writers I work with atm are people that I consistently pieces to, but it's not their job to track how it's doing — that's my job. Their job is just to write it, and they're solely paid per piece. Asking one of them to also go in and look at analytics reads more like a contractor/strategist type of role than a straight-up writing job, which is fine if that's the route you want to go, but would be compensated a lot differently  imo

text: Based on past chats, I'm inferring that you've got a writer that's an engineer, or engineer-adjacent.  Anyone like that will certainly have the chops to navigate GA to the point where they can say, "yep, I can see that this article attracted 200 visitors in the past week."  But what's less likely is for that person to have the context to say whether that's a good result or not.  IOW, data without insight.

elements.text: Based on past chats, I'm inferring that you've got a writer that's an engineer, or engineer-adjacent.  Anyone like that will certainly have the chops to navigate GA to the point where they can say, "yep, I can see that this article attracted 200 visitors in the past week."  But what's less likely is for that person to have the context to say whether that's a good result or not.  IOW, data without insight.

text: Personally, in your situation, I wouldn't bother administering a shared analytics account with them, and rather just set goals and share the data and results with them, feeding that information back into your planning together to tune the approach.

elements.text: Personally, in your situation, I wouldn't bother administering a shared analytics account with them, and rather just set goals and share the data and results with them, feeding that information back into your planning together to tune the approach.

text:
Have had pretty inexpensive results with promoting content with paid ads on Facebook on since January.

Felt like it was a good use of funds since those people end up in a retargeting campaign and in some ways they are more targeted than blog visitors.

text: Do any content/digital marketers here have tips on creating Google Analytics reports to highlight performance only on specified pages (20-30 pages)? The use case is creating a view so a Campaign manager can see how all of the blog posts, etc. tied to a specific campaign are performing.

elements.text: Do any content/digital marketers here have tips on creating Google Analytics reports to highlight performance only on specified pages (20-30 pages)? The use case is creating a view so a Campaign manager can see how all of the blog posts, etc. tied to a specific campaign are performing.

text: Our SEM team is working on this right now. We have seen an uptick in visits and registers.

elements.text: Our SEM team is working on this right now. We have seen an uptick in visits and registers.

text:
Simplest way is to <https://klientboost.com/analytics/google-analytics-regex/|use regex>. If you put URLs plus the pipe/$ operator in the search bar you can limit to the pages you want.

For example:

first-page-url$|second-page-url$|third-page-url$

attachments.title: Google Analytics RegEx: Ultimate Super Powered Guide To Data Tracking
attachments.text: Google Analytics regex (regular expressions) allow you to direct Analytics to ignore defaults while organizing data according to patterns or criteria you define. Learn the default rules and how to create customized ones that can be applied, so that you can filter and categorize for accurate tracking and reporting.
attachments.fallback: KlientBoost: Google Analytics RegEx: Ultimate Super Powered Guide To Data Tracking

elements.text: Simplest way is to

text: <@UJG9WTEKG> We retarget with demo CTA’s after content click. The funny thing though is the cold demo ads (not retargeting) are performing at a lower CPA and higher CTR then the retargeting, so there is more room to grow with the cold audience but might need a warming sequence of ads on the front end since the show up rate has been about 10% lower than non ad audience

text: Hi everyone. I'm new to a Senior Content Role. It feels strange after working in my last role for four years. Here's my question. How do you dive in and train yourself on your company's content as a new team member? I'm listening to sales calls, diving into the blog, and looking into analytics - but I'd love to know if I'm missing a crucial resource. Thanks all!

elements.text: Hi everyone. I'm new to a Senior Content Role. It feels strange after working in my last role for four years. Here's my question. How do you dive in and train yourself on your company's content as a new team member? I'm listening to sales calls, diving into the blog, and looking into analytics - but I'd love to know if I'm missing a crucial resource. Thanks all!

text: Look at what the competition is doing, too

elements.text: Look at what the competition is doing, too

text:
• See if you can receive all emails promoting content that go out to customers and prospects. Experience your content through the lens of your audience.
• Pretend you’re PersonaX and walk through your company’s website, trying to find information that’s relevant just to you. 
• Do a content audit. I like to put key personas on one axis and stages of the buying process on the other, and fill in the blanks to see where gaps exist, where a glut of unpromoted content exists, etc.

elements.text: See if you can receive all emails promoting content that go out to customers and prospects. Experience your content through the lens of your audience.
Pretend you’re PersonaX and walk through your company’s website, trying to find information that’s relevant just to you.

Do a content audit. I like to put key personas on one axis and stages of the buying process on the other, and fill in the blanks to see where gaps exist, where a glut of unpromoted content exists, etc.

text: Paid ads on Facebook and LinkedIn is part of our promotion playbook for gated content. We do it on an ongoing basis, every time we launch a new piece of content. The ads themselves are handled by our digital/paid team, but our content team advises on the copy and creative).  The main goal is to drive new MQLs and get new people onto our newsletter list / at the top of the funnel. Our spend is pretty consistent from month to month. Yes, we've found it to be an effective use of funds and bringing more people into our funnel. we've also been able to connect our paid content ads to bottom-line metrics like demos.

elements.text: Paid ads on Facebook and LinkedIn is part of our promotion playbook for gated content. We do it on an ongoing basis, every time we launch a new piece of content. The ads themselves are handled by our digital/paid team, but our content team advises on the copy and creative).  The main goal is to drive new MQLs and get new people onto our newsletter list / at the top of the funnel. Our spend is pretty consistent from month to month. Yes, we've found it to be an effective use of funds and bringing more people into our funnel. we've also been able to connect our paid content ads to bottom-line metrics like demos.

text: I really like this line about conclusions from an <https://www.animalz.co/blog/how-to-write-a-blog-post-outline/|Animalz blog post>: "good conclusions are more than rote summaries of the article: they offer something _extra,_ like a souvenir purchased from the final stop on your epic journey. This could be an extra data point, a bonus step to the process you outlined, or a new framing of your argument—whatever is required to help the reader take a logical next step after reading your article."
